title: Casual jobs are here to stay: Albanese
text:
Similarly, Jobs and Skills Australia would oversee the adequacy of Australia's vocational education sector and identify current and future demands.

"It will work with business and unions to harness insights from industry to ensure that our VET system delivers the trainees and apprentices that our country needs,'' he said.

"We have a labour market characterised by the mismatch between what workers have to offer, and what employers need.''

The government accused Mr Albanese of ripping off its National Skills Commission.

Mr Albanese's speech sought to recalibrate Labor's policy philosophy towards one that creates economic growth and jobs, not just the tax and redistribution agenda it took to the last election.

Mr Albanese has also sought to portray himself as forward-looking.

Flexible worker protections

Increased casualisation of the workforce has been a growing concern of the labour movement for years because of the insecurity it creates for workers.

Advertisement

Mr Albanese said the IR system needed to be revamped to look after casual workers – both those who chose to work casually and those who did not.

"Our industrial relations system is being strained by the emergence of new forms of employment arrangements,'' he said.

"One such trend is growth in intermediated or on-demand employment, such as the growth in the gig economy.

"We want people to elect to take on this form of work because it benefits them, not have it imposed on them by lack of choice.

"And not as a tool to de-unionise workplaces as a step to lowering wages and conditions.''

He said worker protections needed to become as flexible as the workplace and Labor would examine policy options such as portable entitlements.

The acceptance of casualisation could rankle the union movement, elements of which are already angry at Labor for its support in Parliament last week of three free trade agreements.

But Mr Albanese backed that in his speech, saying supporting worker protection was "not the same as supporting protectionism''.

Advertisement

"A trading nation such as ours cannot depend on the latter. Protectionism detracts from growth and punishes consumers and business.

"But protections are different. They are the insurance we take on to reduce uncertainty, strengthen confidence, manage risk and support enterprise.''

Carr calls policy shift 'spin'

Mr Albanese also used the speech to recast Labor's climate change pitch towards one of job creation by heralding a manufacturing boom that could emanate from the transition towards renewable energy.

The shift in policy emphasis is starting to rankle internally with senior Senator and Left factional figure Kim Carr openly questioning the post-election epiphany of Mr Albanese and senior shadow ministers. He called the message shift "spin".

"Not one of those senior people argued against the policies at the time, not one of them,'' said Senator Carr, who believes Labor should keep the policy agenda it took to the election.

"Not one of them in the shadow cabinet spoke or voted against them. No one opposed the spending on schools, on hospitals, on childcare workers, on the environment, on the defence policies or any of the other commitments that we made.

"You can argue that we’ve got to spend less, that’s a reasonable proposition, but you’ve got to say where we should spend less, and how that would then end up defining the Labor Party."
description: Accepting workforce casualisation was here to stay, the Labor leader said the industrial relations system needed to protect those who chose to work multiple jobs, such as those in the gig economy, as well as those who did not..
